Key Arguments: The distinction between 'misinformation' and 'disinformation' should be removed, focusing instead on whether content could cause serious harm.
The definition of 'good faith' should be tightened to include satire and parody as potentially harmful content.
The definition of a 'news organisation' should be carefully examined to prevent exploitation by misinformation agents.
Data gathering powers should be strengthened to provide more robust data access to researchers and civil society.
The Bill takes an overly narrow, techno-centric view of misinformation, ignoring broader socio-political contexts.
Main Themes: Role of satire and parody in spreading misinformation
Definition and role of news organizations
Notable Quotes: We believe that the Bill takes an overly narrow view of the problem of misinformation, positioning it as largely a technological problem.
Humour can be used as a catch-all to legitimise highly problematic and harmful content online.
The Bill, as it stands, neglects coordinated behaviour, and this needs to be addressed by evaluating the context of content rather than just the content itself.
